title: Police raid on ABC may scare off whistleblowers: SC
text:
While the AFP was already investigating David McBride, the whistleblower who exposed the alleged misconduct, Dr Collins said there were other sources involved in the story that were not suspected by the AFP.

Dr Collins suggested these sources deserved protection of the type offered by legal professional privilege or public interest immunity.

The barrister invoked the implied freedom of political communication, which in certain circumstances prevents legislation being written or interpreted in a way that limits political speech.

AFP's 'common' defence

But Neil Williams, SC, for the AFP, said there was “no real basis” to the argument that the implied freedom should be considered when granting a search warrant, which is granted under Commonwealth criminal law.

He also said the AFP warrant was requested and used in line with "common" police investigation procedures, wherein officers identify a suspect then seek evidence against that person while simultaneously ruling out other options.

“Not only is this a very common method, but it’s common because it’s effective and it’s valid," Mr Williams said.

The ABC's reliance on the implied freedom of political communication – one of four grounds on which it hopes to get the warrant overturned – built on arguments it made in court on Monday that the reporting of the Afghan Files was of public importance.

Advertisement

"These stories were not trivial tittle-tattle. They were stories of vital importance to the Australian people," Dr Collins told the court.

On Monday, ABC lawyer Michael Rippon said the AFP told the broadcaster it did not want “any sensationalist headlines” about the raids.

He also said that during the raid, it was “made clear” to the ABC’s legal staff that a public interest defence afforded to journalists under the criminal code was “only a defence” and “didn’t stop them from investigating matters”.

Mr Rippon was one of the ABC staff who supervised the raid.

Tuesday's court date was the second day of a full court hearing into the validity of the warrant. Justice Abraham adjourned the hearing early – it was originally slated to take three days – and will deliver her judgment at a later date.

The AFP previously agreed not to access the documents it seized in the raid, which are being held on USB sticks, and on Tuesday gave an undertaking to continue this commitment until a week after the judgment.

Mr Williams warned, however, that the undertaking may not be extended should the ABC appeal Justice Abraham’s decision if they lose the case.
description: Upholding the Australian Federal Police's warrant to raid the ABC's Ultimo offices may scare people away from reporting wrongdoing to journalists, a leading media barrister has warned.
